case_title: PRADEEP KUMAR HAR SARAN LAL vs ASSESSING OFFICER
case_number: Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 414 of 1996
legal_issues: Validity of notice under section 148 of the Income Tax Act, 1961
Applicability of section 44-AC for computing profits
Jurisdiction of Assessing Officer under section 143(1)(a) and section 147
Merger of intimation in appellate order
key_points: The petitioner, a partnership firm engaged in the business of alcoholic liquor, challenged the notice issued under section 148 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
The Assessing Officer had initially computed taxable income under section 44-AC, which was later set aside by the Commissioner of Income-tax (Appeals).
The court held that adjustments made under section 143(1)(a) were ab initio void as they involved debatable issues.
The court clarified that intimation under section 143(1)(a) does not constitute an assessment.
The Assessing Officer was justified in initiating reassessment proceedings under section 147, as income had escaped assessment.
Failure to issue notice under section 143(2) does not preclude the Assessing Officer from initiating reassessment under section 147.
judgment_summary: The petition was dismissed, allowing the Assessing Officer to proceed with the notice under section 148 and pass an order on merits without being influenced by prior observations.

references.case_name: A. Sanyasi Rao v. Government of Andhra Pradesh
Union of India v. A. Sanyasi Rao
Jorawar Singh Baid v. Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax
